questions.question: What is the minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephroticsyndrome?

A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of generalized swelling of the body and frothyurine. Urinary examination revealed grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fattycasts. There were no red blood cells in the urine. Which of the following statements about hercondition is true?

options.A: IgA nephropathy is the likely diagnosis.
options.B: It is associated with low C3 levels.
options.C: No IgG or C3 deposition is seen on renal biopsy.
options.D: Alport syndrome is the likely diagnosis.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario in this child is strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due tominimal change disease (MCD). It is characterized by the absence of immune deposits on biopsyand histopathological examination.It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years).Biopsy findings of MCD are as follows:•Light microscopy - glomeruli appear normal (hence called 'minimal change')• Immunofluorescence studies - no Ig or complement deposits779• Electron microscopy - diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells(podocytopathy)

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy is brought for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome3 months ago and had been started on a course of oral prednisolone. During the current visit,no improvement is noted with regards to facial puffiness and urine analysis reveals grade 3proteinuria. Mutations in all of the following are associated with this condition except:
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. It can be causeddue to mutations in the following components of the glomerular filtration barrier:•Nephrin, podocin - are molecular components of the slit diaphragm complex• Alpha-actinin 4 - is a component of the foot process cytoskeletonMegalin is not a component of the glomerular filtration barrier. It is present in proximalconvoluted tubular cells. Mutations in megalin may lead to some proteinuria but not nephroticsyndrome because glomerular filtration of proteins is not affected.

questions.question: A 67-year-old man presents with sudden onset flank pain and hematuria. Ultrasound revealsenlargement of both kidneys. He is a known case of membranous nephropathy. What is thelikely pathophysiology for his current presentation?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario in a patient suffering from membranous nephropathy, which is a typeof nephrotic syndrome, is suggestive of renal vein thrombosis. It is due to the loss of antithrombinIII (an endogenous anticoagulant) in urine.Renal vein thrombosis is most often a consequence of a hypercoagulable state. In adults, it is mostcommonly seen in patients with membranous nephropathy.Nephrotic syndrome-PathophysiologyIncreased glomerular permeability↓Increased filtration of plasma proteinsUrinary loss of proteincarrying hormones,metals, and vitaminsTubulardamageTubulardysfunctionAlteration incoagulationfactorsThromboembolismIncreased tubularreabsorption offiltered proteinsTubularcatabolismof albuminAlbuminuriaHypoalbuminemiaEdemaOMARROWAltered rate ofturnover ofimmunoglobulinsMalnutritionIncreasedinfectionsIncreased hepaticsynthesis oflipoproteinsHyperlipoproteinemiaLipiduria

questions.question: In a patient with nephrotic syndrome, all of the following are decreased except:
questions.explanation: In nephrotic syndrome, there is an increase in fibrinogen levels.780The following proteins are increased in nephrotic syndrome:• Fibrinogen•Lipoproteins - due to increased synthesisThe following proteins are decreased in nephrotic syndrome as a consequence of selectiveproteinuria:•Albumin - the largest proportion of protein lost in nephrotic syndrome.• Transferrin• Cholecalciferol-binding protein• Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)• Ferritin•Coagulation factors• Antithrombin III

questions.question: A patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-rangeproteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (refluxnephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmentalglomerulosclerosis (FSGS).FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, withdegeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes.Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins andincreased extracellular matrix deposition.FSGS is classified as follows:• Primary•Idiopathic FSGS• Secondary• HIV associated• Heroin addiction•Sickle cell disease•Obesity•Hypertensive nephropathy• Renal conditions• Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)•Renal ablation• Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia• Reflux nephropathy781• Inherited• Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis -Light microscopyFocal segmental glomerulosclerosis -Light microscopyGlobal and focalglomerulosclerosisElectron microscopy of FSGS shows:• Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes• Focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells• Absence of electron-dense deposits

questions.question: Patients diagnosed with which variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are likely to havethe worst prognosis?
questions.explanation: The collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is associated with the worstprognosis.782There are 5 variants of FSGS:•Collapsing variant - poor prognosis•Glomerular tip variant - good prognosis• Cellular variant•Perihilar variant• Not otherwise specified - most commonGiven below is a histological image of collapsing glomerulopathy showing the involvement of theentire glomerular tuft and proliferation of visceral epithelial cells.Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis -Light microscopy

questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of theglomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous nephropathy.784Membranous nephropathy -Light microscopyMembranous nephropathy -Light microscopyThickening ofglomerularcapillary wallMembranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in theadults/elderly. questions.question: Mesangial deposits are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Mesangial deposits are seen in the following conditions:•IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)•Henoch–Schonlein purpura•Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis• Lupus nephritis classes I and II• Resolving postinfectious glomerulonephritis786

questions.question: A 29-year-old man presented with complaints of blood in his urine. Urine analysis waspositive for proteins and red cell casts. A renal biopsy was done as shown below.Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed granular deposits of C3 on either side of theglomerular basement membrane but was negative for IgG, Cıq, and C4. What is the likelydiagnosis?770
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario, immunofluorescence findings, and the image showing proliferatingmesangial cells and capillary endothelial cells are suggestive of membranoproliferativeglomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease.Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis -Light microscopyMembranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis -Light microscopyThe following image shows bright deposits scattered along capillary walls and in the mesangiumby immunofluorescence microscopy with antibodies to C3.787Dense-deposit disease -ImmunofluorescenceDense-deposit disease -ImmunofluorescenceDeposits in capillary walland mesangiumThis condition belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies and primarily affectschildren and young adults. It is associated with a dysregulation in the alternative complementpathway. It is clinically and morphologically similar to MPGN type 1 but pathogenetically distinctfrom it.In this condition, a circulating autoantibody called C3 nephritic factor is present,which stabilizes the C3 convertase enzyme. The stabilized C3 convertase enhances C3 activationand consumption causing hypocomplementemia. Patients will have consistently decreasedserum C3 levels, but normal C1 and C4 levels.The prognosis is poor, with about half of these patients progressing to end-stage renal disease(ESRD).

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image?MARROW
questions.explanation: 788The given electrophoresis shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which isclassically seen in nephrotic syndrome.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of primary nephritic syndrome?
questions.explanation: IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is the most common cause of primary nephritic syndrome in theworld.Nephritic syndrome is characterized by:•••• Acute onset of hematuria-Urinalysis red cell castsDiminished glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (oliguria)• Mild to moderate proteinuria• Hypertension• Azotemia

questions.question: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showedmesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen onimmunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillaryproliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgAnephropathy (Berger's disease).It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrenthematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium.Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tractinfection.IgA Nephropathy - ImmunofluorescenceMesangial deposits789The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch-Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder ofchildren which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in themesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.question: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops fever, oliguria, periorbital edema and smoky cola-coloredurine 2-weeks after recovery from sore throat. His renal biopsy image is given below. Whichof the following statements is false about the given condition?

options.A: A rapidly progressive form with oliguria develops in 50% of children
options.B: It is a form of proliferative glomerulonephritis
options.C: Granular IgG and C3 deposits are seen on immunofluorescence
options.D: Dome-shaped subepithelial humps are seen on electron microscopy

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing hypercellular glomeruli aresuggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Rapidly progressive disease witholiguria is very rare (< 1% of patients).Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritisPost-streptococcal glomerulonephritisHypercellularglomerulusProliferatingcapillariesPost-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. It isusually preceded by an acute streptococcal sore throat or impetigo around 1-4 weeks prior.It usually presents with features of nephritic syndrome including:790• Hematuria• Red cell casts in the urine•Azotemia, oliguria• Hypertension• Mild to moderate proteinuria• EdemaOn microscopy, the following findings are seen:•Light microscopy - enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillaryproliferation)• Electron microscopy - subepithelial humps•Immunofluorescence - granular IgG and C3 deposits on glomerular basement membrane andmesangiumMajority (> 95%) of affected children eventually recover renal function with conservativetherapy.

questions.question: A pathologist is examining the following renal biopsy specimen. What does it show?773

options.A: Proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial cells and WBCs in Bowman space
options.B: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wallProliferating mesangial cells and increased matrix deposition in the mesangiumd) Proliferation of capillaries with fibrin depositionQuestion 17:A patient with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure underwent renal biopsy. It revealed thepresence of crescents in most of the glomeruli. Immunofluorescence finding is shown in theimage below. What is the diagnosis?a) Acute post-infectious glomerulonephritis774b) Membranous nephropathy

questions.explanation: The given image shows a crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal and visceral epithelialcells and leukocytes within the Bowman capsule. It is a characteristic feature of rapidlyprogressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or crescentic glomerulonephritis.Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis -Light microscopyCrescentRPGN is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis andformation of crescents. It is usually immune-mediated and may be associated withcirculating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), anti-GBM antibodies, and antinuclearantibodies (ANA).791Injury to the glomerular capillary wall leads to the escape of procoagulant factors and cytokines inthe Bowman space. This triggers:• Proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells mostly parietal, but also some visceral cells• Recruitment of leukocytes and fibroblasts•Pathognomonic crescents due to the circumferential accumulation of these cells and fibrin-The crescents progressively compress the capillary tuft. This results in a rapid decline ofglomerular filtration rate (GFR) and, consequently, acute kidney injury (AKI). Thus, the degree ofcrescent formation correlates with the severity and the prognosis of the disease.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with normal findings on light microscopy and diffuse thinning of theglomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy are highly suggestive of benign familialhematuria (thin basement membrane disease).It is a type of hereditary nephritis manifested clinically by familial asymptomatic hematuria.The following are the differences between Alport's syndrome and benign familial hematuria.FeaturesInheritanceAffected proteinHearing LossOcular abnormalitiesAlport's syndromeX-linked (most common)Autosomal inheritanceα5 chain of type IV collagen (Most commonly)PresentPresentBenign familial hematuriaAutosomal inheritanceα3 or α4 chains of type IV collagen.AbsentAbsent793FeaturesProgress to end-stage renal diseaseElectron microscopyAlport's syndromeYesIrregularthickeningandthinningof basement membraneSplitting and lamination of lamina densa -basket-weaveappearanceBenign familial hematuriaNoDiffuse thinningof the glomerular basement membranePrognosisPoorGood

questions.question: What is the most common manifestation of Alport's syndrome?
questions.explanation: The most common manifestation of Alport syndrome is gross or microscopic hematuria,frequently accompanied by red cell casts.Proteinuria and oliguria may develop later in the disease, and rarely, nephrotic syndromedevelops. The deafness may be subtle requiring sensitive testing.There are no significant light microscopy changes in Alport syndrome. On electron microscopy,the glomerular basement membrane shows:• Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning)• Pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa - basket-weave appearanceElectron Microscopy - Alport Syndrome794Electron Microscopy - Alport SyndromeIrregularglomerularmembrane

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showedproteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, andcotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?776
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff(PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease. It occurs in patientswith diabetic nephropathy.Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease796Kimmelstiel-Wilson diseaseNodularglomerulosclerosisThe following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:• Glomerular lesions -•Capillary basement membrane thickening•• Diffuse mesangial sclerosisNodular glomerulosclerosis/ Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease• Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis• Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis•Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitisOption A: In amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix,forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid.Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis andsclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along theentire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.

Among the given options, anti- GBM antibodytesting should be done, since it is a part of the work-up of RPGN.797Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis -Light microscopyRapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis -Light microscopyCrescentsCrescentsType 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition,antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of theGBM.Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are:• Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basementmembrane• Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focaldisruptions without any immune complex deposition.A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture'ssyndrome.Option A: ANA testing is done if SLE is suspected. questions.question: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in:
questions.explanation: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B.MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephroticpicture.The causes of MPGN are as follows:• Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)• Secondary MPGN•System lupus erythematosus (SLE)•α1-antitrypsin deficiency• Infections hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrialshunts, chronic visceral abscesses•-Malignancies chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and thecapillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis. There are 2 types ofMPGN:• Type I - It is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes and mesangiocapillaryproliferation.• Type II - It is now known as dense-deposit disease. It belongs to a group of disorders called C3glomerulopathies.Light microscopy findings of MPGN are as follows:• Lobular glomeruli with proliferating mesangial cells, capillary endothelium, and infiltratingleukocytes (endocapillary proliferation)• Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. Itis especially evident in silver or PAS stains.799Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis -Light microscopyMembranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis -Light microscopy800
